    • Introduction to the `{rmexact}` R Package

    Introduction to the {rmexact} R Package

    rmexact-intro.Rmd

    Introduction

    This package contains three tests to evaluate the assumption of random mating in autotetraploids, which are organisms with four copies of homologous chromosomes. Let \(y = (y_0, y_1, y_2, y_3, y_4)\) be the vector of genotype counts, where \(y_k\) is the number of individuals in our sample with genotye \(k\). Let \(n = y_0 + y_1 + y_2 + y_3 + y_4\) be the sample size. Let \(q = (q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3, q_4)\) be the genotype frequencies of the population. Let \(p = (p_0, p_1, p_2)\) be the gamete frequencies, where \(p_k\) is the proportion of gametes produced in the population with genotype \(k\). This package evaluates the two models \[ H_0: y \sim \text{Multinom}(n, p * p)\\ H_A: y \sim \text{Multinom}(n, q) \] where “\(*\)” denotes discrete linear convolution, and \(\text{Multinom}\) represents the multinomial distribution. This package takes three approaches:

    1. tetexact(): An exact test using sufficient statistics for tetraploids.
    2. rmslrt(): An exact test using the split likelihood ratio (Wasserman et al., 2020) for any even ploidy level.
    3. rmchisq(): A standard chi-squared test for any ploidy level.

    This vignette will cover these three tests. Let’s load the package into R

    library(rmexact)

    An Exact Test Using Sufficient Statistics

    tetexact(): This function will calculate the exact \(p\)-value using sufficient statistics. A vector containing the genotype counts should be inserted to run this function. If the user desires to obtain a log \(p\)-value, set log_p = TRUE to make it happen.

    Below is an example:

    res <- c(18, 44, 69, 53, 16) 
tetexact(y = res)
#> [1] 0.4271683

    An Exact Test Using the Split Likelihood Ratio

    rmslrt(): This function will calculate the \(p\)-value using the split likelihood ratio test. A vector containing the genotype counts, the proportional split, and the number of iterations should be inserted to run this function. If the user desires to obtain a log \(p\)-value, set log_p = TRUE to make it happen.

    Below is an example:

    nvec1 <- c(18, 44, 69, 53, 16) 
rmslrt(nvec = nvec1, sprop = 0.5, nrep = 100)
#> $q1
#> [1] 0.08 0.20 0.39 0.26 0.07
#> 
#> $q2
#>                                0          1          2 
#> 0.09115473 0.23619918 0.33833740 0.24011024 0.09419845 
#> 
#> $nvec1
#> [1]  8 20 39 26  7
#> 
#> $nvec2
#> [1] 10 24 30 27  9
#> 
#> $pval
#> [1] 1

    A Chi-squared Test

    rmchisqr(): This function will calculate the chi-squared \(p\)-value. A vector containing the genotype counts should be inserted to run this function. If the user desires to obtain a log \(p\)-value, set log_p = TRUE to make it happen.

    Below is an example:

    nvec <- c(18, 44, 69, 53, 16) 
rmchisq(nvec = nvec)
#> [1] 0.6544526

    References

    • Wasserman, L., Ramdas, A., & Balakrishnan, S. (2020). Universal inference. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 117(29), 16880-16890. doi:10.1073/pnas.1922664117.
